conversation.content: [hollow] Look at this place—half the backdrop's still unpainted, the platforms aren't even secured, and now we're supposed to just what, miracle this into existence with pocket change?
I've been calling everyone I know since midnight, trying to find someone, anyone, who might throw us a lifeline here. [exhales heavily] Nobody's answering anymore.
We need at least thirty thousand just for materials, never mind the crew overtime we'd have to pay to get this remotely ready.
The cast doesn't even know yet—they're going to show up tomorrow for dress rehearsal expecting a full set, expecting everything we promised them. [bitter laugh]
[defeated] Three months of work.
[wearily] I keep thinking about Sarah's face when she sees that her big scene's backdrop is literally bare plywood because we can't afford the scenic artist to finish it.
[sinking into a chair] Maybe we should just call it now, send out the cancellation notices before people buy more tickets to a show that won't happen.
[desperately] We can't—the theater's already taken deposits for next month's bookings based on our run, and if we cancel, they'll sue us for breach of contract.
[laughs emptily] So we're trapped between putting on an embarrassment of a show or getting buried in legal fees we definitely can't afford either.
[crumbling] My entire reputation is tied to this production, five years of building contacts and trust, and it's all going to collapse in forty-eight hours.
You think I don't know that? This was supposed to be my breakthrough design, the one that finally got me noticed beyond community theater. [voice breaking] Now it'll just be remembered as a disaster.
[exhausted] I've already maxed out two credit cards trying to keep the lights on here, literally, because the venue wanted payment upfront after hearing about the investor.
[quietly] What if we stripped it down, made it minimalist on purpose, sold it as an artistic choice instead of admitting we're broke?
[drained] The marketing's already out there showing the elaborate Victorian setting, and critics are expecting what we promised—we'd look like complete amateurs trying to spin this.
[sighs] The wood we have might be enough for the essential platforms if we forget about the second level entirely and just work with what's already built.
[hopelessly] Even if we manage that, we still need someone to run the lighting board since Marcus quit yesterday when he found out about the money.
[emptily] I know the basics from tech week, could probably fumble through it if we simplify the cues down to just essential visibility lighting.
[staring at the half-built set] Twenty-three investors said no, twenty-three, and the one who said yes pulled out after his lawyers reviewed our financials.
[flatly] We should have seen this coming when the initial budget meetings kept getting pushed back, but we were so desperate to make it work.
[barely audible] At least we tried, right? [long pause] That has to count for something when everyone's asking what went wrong.

scenario: The set designer and production coordinator meet in the empty theater at 3 AM after learning their lead investor has pulled funding, leaving them 48 hours before opening night with half the set unfinished.
